content: The "Financial Institutions Examination Fairness and Reform Act" is cited as the short title. The definition of a financial institution is amended to include various types of institutions and nondepository covered persons supervised by the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection. The Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council Act of 1978 is amended to include a new section on the timeliness of examination reports. The Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council Act of 1978 is amended to include a new section requiring Federal financial institutions regulatory agencies to provide a final examination report to a financial institution within 60 days after the exit interview or the provision of additional information by the institution. If a financial institution is not part of a resident examiner program, the exit interview must occur within 9 months of the examination, with the possibility of extension by written notice from the regulatory agency. The Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council Act of 1978 is amended to require Federal financial institutions regulatory agencies to provide a final examination report to a financial institution within 60 days after the exit interview or provision of additional information. Financial institutions can request an extension for completing the examination, and the agency must include all examination materials relied upon in the final report. The Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council Act of 1978 is amended to include an Office of Independent Examination Review, overseen by an Independent Examination Review Director. The Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council Act of 1978 is amended to establish the Office of Independent Examination Review, headed by the Independent Examination Review Director. The Director serves a 5-year term, can hire staff, and investigates complaints regarding examinations from financial institutions. The Office of Independent Examination Review conducts regular meetings with financial institutions to discuss examination procedures and policies, reviews examination quality assurance, and ensures adherence to established standards. The Office of Independent Examination Review conducts reviews of examination procedures and policies, prioritizing factors related to the safety and soundness of the US financial system. They report annually to relevant committees on compliance with examination report timeliness and recommendations for improvements. The Director of the Office of Independent Examination Review must maintain confidentiality regarding meetings, discussions, and information provided by financial institutions. If the Director is removed from office, the reasons for removal must be communicated to specific congressional committees. SEC. 5. RIGHT TO INDEPENDENT REVIEW OF MATERIAL SUPERVISORY DETERMINATIONS. The Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council Act of 1978 is further amended to include the right to independent review of material supervisory determinations. A financial institution has the right to obtain an independent review of a material supervisory determination in a final examination report. The institution must file a written notice with the Independent Examination Review Director within 60 days of receiving the report, identifying the determination in question and providing reasons for believing it is incorrect or should be modified. The financial institution can request any information relied upon by the agency in the final report that is not in their possession. The Director will determine the appeal on the record or refer it to an Administrative Law Judge for a confidential hearing within 60 days of receiving the petition for review. The Director or Administrative Law Judge conducts a de novo review to determine the agency's decision independently based on relevant statutes and evidence from any hearing. The Director's decision must be made within 60 days and is considered final agency action binding on the agency in question. The FFIEC may conduct a limited review if an agency believes the Director's decision poses a threat to a financial institution's safety and soundness. The review aims to determine if there is substantial evidence supporting the imminent threat. The Financial Stability Oversight Council (FSOC) has the authority to make a final determination within 30 days of a notice being filed regarding a financial institution's safety and soundness. This determination is considered final agency action and is binding. Financial institutions have the right to petition for judicial review within 60 days of the decision. The Director is required to report annually to the Committee. The Director must report annually to the House Committee on Financial Services and the Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs on actions taken under this section. The report should include the types of issues reviewed and their results. The report cannot disclose information about individual financial institutions or any confidential data. Additionally, federal financial institutions regulatory agencies are prohibited from retaliating against financial institutions or delaying agency actions that would benefit them for exercising appellate rights under this section. The section prohibits federal financial institutions regulatory agencies from retaliating against financial institutions or delaying agency actions that would benefit them for exercising appellate rights. It also clarifies that the agencies can still take enforcement or supervisory actions related to a material supervisory determination under review. SEC. 6. ADDITIONAL AMENDMENTS. The Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994 is amended to include the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection in subsection (a) and protect insured depository institutions or credit unions from retaliation by agencies in subsection (b). Retaliation includes delaying consideration or withholding approval of actions. The Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994 is amended to protect insured depository institutions or credit unions from retaliation by agencies, including delaying or withholding approval of actions. Safeguards are required to protect institutions from retaliation for exercising their rights under the Act. The Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994 is amended to protect institutions from retaliation by agencies. This includes adding new clauses regarding issues listed in exam reports and suspension of expedited processing status. The Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994 is amended to protect institutions from retaliation by agencies, including issues listed in exam reports and suspension of expedited processing status. Amendments to various acts include inserting the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection in the Federal Credit Union Act and updating definitions in the Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council Act of 1978. The Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994 is amended to protect institutions from retaliation by agencies, including issues listed in exam reports and suspension of expedited processing status. The amendment includes adding the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection to the list of agencies and updating definitions in the Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council Act of 1978. SEC. 7 of the Federal Reserve Act is amended to reduce surplus funds from $7,500,000,000 to $7,324,285,000, effective June 1, 2018. The amendment was passed by the House of Representatives on March 15, 2018.
